Legislative deadlines are looming, and police reform is on the chopping block if we don't take immediate action. Contact key committee chairs and vice-chairs and ask them that these critical police reform bills are scheduled for hearing ASAP.

Contact the Senate Committee on Public Safety, Intergovernmental, and Military Affairs

  • Senator Nishihara (Chair) 808-586-6970, sennishihara@capitol.hawaii.gov
  • Senator English (Vice-Chair) 808-587-7225, senenglish@capitol.hawaii.gov

Sample:

Aloha, Senator Nishihara/Senator English. My name is {include "first_name"} and I am contacting you to request that the Senate Committee on Public Safety, Intergovernmental, and Military Affairs immediately schedule a hearing for S.B. 783, S.B. 726, S.B. 30, and S.B. 742. I am a voter, and these bills will help protect our communities and increase police accountability and transparency.

Contact the House Committee on Judiciary and Hawaiian Affairs.

  • Representative Nakashima (Chair) 808-586-6680, repnakashima@Capitol.hawaii.gov
  • Representative Matayoshi (Vice-Chair) 808-586-8470, repmatayoshi@Capitol.hawaii.gov

Sample:

Aloha, Representative Nakashima/Representative Matayoshi. My name is {include "first_name"} and I am contacting you to request that the House Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs immediately schedule a hearing for H.B. 666, H.B. 1382, and H.B. 1381. I am a voter, and these bills will help protect our communities and increase police accountability and transparency.

Learn more about the bills:

Qualified Immunity Bill

HB 666 and SB 783, relating to law enforcement. This bill allows victims of police violence to sue individual officers for damages under state law and in state court. The legal doctrine of "qualified immunity" – which has been used by federal courts to shield officers from accountability – would not apply to these lawsuits. This bill offers legal recourse for people who have been harmed by police violence and their families.

Breonna's Law

HB 1382 and SB 726, relating to policing. This bill explicitly bans "no-knock" warrants and requires officers to wait at least thirty seconds before entering a house, store, or other building when executing a warrant. It also requires officers to execute warrants in uniform.

Demilitarization Bill

HB 1381 and SB 30, relating to law enforcement. This bill prohibits police from acquiring certain military-grade equipment and weapons, such as armored vehicles and Long Range Acoustic Devices (LRADs). This bill also bans police use of "less-lethal" weapons, like tear gas, against protestors.

Policing Data bill

SB 742, relating to policing. This bill requires each county police department to collect certain data around police stops, use of force, and arrests, and submit annual reports to the legislature.
